entry.title: Flying to Sandakan and Into the Rainforest
entry.content:
After enjoying Kuching and it’s beautiful town, including the amazing food festival that just happened to take place during the nights we were there, we flew north to a town called Sandakan. From Sandakan we took a taxi to a small place called Sepilok.

Sepilok is most known for its Orangutan rehabilitation center which was located just a few minutes from our hotel. The Sepilok rehabilitation center is a park where they take care of orphaned orangutans until they are grown enough to take care of them selves, this usually takes about 10-12 years and requires a lot of effort. Now, taking care of orphaned orangutans and teaching them everything their mother were suppose to teach them is truly an awesome thing, one could however raise the question about how their mothers died in the first place, I’ll leave that one to the reader though. The park has “feeding times” at 10 am and 3 pm and you would want to be there at least 20 minutes earlier to get a descent view (it’s really crowded).

My personal favorite however was the Labuk Bay proboscis monkey sanctuary where you could see (and actually get really close to) the proboscis monkeys. If you are lucky enough you’ll will also the silver leaf monkey and the famous hornbill birds.

All in all, this was a great a day and we managed to see everything we wanted. Unfortunately me and Luisa got sick the other day so we’ve been struggling with fever and this fucking annoying runny nose. It has been very annoying two days, but it finally seems to be heading in the right direction, knock on wood.

Now heading of to Sukau and Osman homestay for some real jungle experience.

entry.title: Cat City and the War Veteran
entry.content:
This morning we arrived at Kuching, the capital of Sarawak. We had to get up at 4am so we were pretty torn out when we arrived. We fought the tiredness though and decided to get to know the city a little better with a walk. It didn’t take long before we fell in love Kuching and it’s beautiful Sarawak river.

Sarawak River is amazingly cool and runs through the whole city acting as an important transport area. We decided to take one of the tour boats (for 20 ringit) which goes both ways on the river for an hour. The tour boat isn’t really “guided” since it’s only provided by a driver whom didn’t seem to show any interest at all in pointing out stuff for us. Luckily we met a guy called Charlie and his wife Chris who knew the city really well. Turns out that they go to Malaysia twice a year, and that Charlie is an old war veteran and was invited by the Malaysian Government this year to celebrate that 50 years had gone by since the conflict between Malaysia and Indonesia ended. Pretty interesting fella who definitely liked to talk (picture with him below).

We ended the day at the Black Bean who happened to serve the best coffee in town. Small, cozy coffee shop with all sorts of coffee and a very friendly staff. If you are up to it, why not enjoy the coffee with some sort of “local fishcake”, it’s suppose to be really good, I however, was not up for it. My friends seemed to like it though.

Lastly, we got totally lost when headed back to Beds Guest House and ended up walking for an hour instead of the “normal 10 minute walk”. Beds Guest House is btw an insanely good guest house with extremely (I mean hotel style) clean rooms and a very friendly staff that will help you with whatever you need. Price is good and we ended up paying 25 ringit each / per night for our own room on the loft. Right outside the guest house you will meet Annie who probably makes one of Kuching’s best Kolo mee, winning!

entry.title: Diving at Perhentian
entry.content:
When I arrived late afternoon on the tenth of July to Perhentian Islands I was terrified, seriously, absolutely terrified. I had planned to go diving with Angel Divers since a friend of a friend knew the owner. I arrived at the diveshop and was greeted by Rob (who’s currently a divemaster there) who asked me if I was up for some diving.

I nervously said that I was and that all I basically wanted to do on the Island was to dive. We decided to go diving in the morning and I went on looking for some accommodation. At the end of the beach there was an interesting place called the butterfly guesthouse where you “signed your self in”. If there was a key on the board, the room was free, and you could take it. No reception, no one to talk to or anything, just a key (if you were lucky, which I actually was, you could run into the guy running the place and he would show you your chalet). The condition of the chalets were pretty poor and unfortunately there was some animals (like bats and rats) hanging around. Even though these chalets provide the best view on the whole Island I only stayed there for a night. I guess I’m a little bit to comfortable for that kind of living. It’s a shame though that the place is falling a part since it’s so freaking cool. Later on I ended up staying directly on the beach in one of Mayas Guest House’s bungalows, which fitted me perfectly.

I did all my diving at Angel Divers and I met some really good friends. The first two weeks we were about ten people that got to know each other really well. This was an amazing experience for me, I still can’t believe how that many people ended up in the same place and everyone just got along. The weeks went by and people started to leave for new adventures. I hadn’t really thought about when to leave but I knew I was going to Borneo for some jungle tracking and a lot more diving. Luckily enough two German girls came by the shop to do some diving before they would hit Borneo. I nervously asked them if I could tag a long for a while since its much funnier to travel with people. They were more than happy to let me tag a long, and for that I’m eternally grateful. Luisa and Isabel are two amazing people and I’ve had so much fun with them (and will for another week or two). They are seriously the kindest friends, and even though I felt a little bit sad about leaving Perhentian, I couldn’t have gotten a better start on my Borneo adventure <3

Thanks again Angel Divers , see you soon again.
